Welsh traders and shoppers adjust to 5p bag charge
Most of the traders and shoppers on Machynlleth High Street support the new law, but there is still an air of rebellion
Share Tweet this Email
Steven Morris guardian.co.uk , Friday 30 September 2011 12.17 BST Comments ( … )
Machynlleth in mid-Wales, where there is some anger and confusion about the bag charge. Photograph: Steve Peake for the Guardian The sun is out, the market is packed but there is an air of rebellion among the stallholders on Machynlleth High Street in mid- Wales .
"It's a ridiculous, stupid law," says David Parry, vender of all kinds of household goods – pots of paint, rope, cigarette lighters. "I'm going to find a way round it. We all will."
From Saturday, Wales will become the first country in the UK to force retailers to charge for single-use carrier bags.
From the largest supermarkets to the most modest corner store or market stall, shopkeepers will be compelled to charge customers at least 5p for the convenience of taking their goods home in a disposable bag.
"I'm not going to charge customers who are spending £10 an extra 5p for a bag to put the goods in," says Parry. "I'll just knock 5p off the price of the goods. I don't think the government should be treating us like children. People should be able to choose how they take their goods home."
David Cameron may have talked tough on single-use bags this week, warning retailers that he may introduce new laws if supermarkets do not take action to reduce their usage.
But the Welsh assembly has got in already. The first minister, Carwyn Jones, has been meeting shopkeepers and shoppers to explain why his country is leading the battle against the bags.
Jones called single use bags a "blight on our landscape" and a " waste of natural resources". His government believes that last year Welsh people took home an average of 273 bags per household from supermarkets alone.
It says local authorities spent £1m clearing them up and expects the charge to reduce usage by 90%. The money raised will not swell government coffers – instead, retailers will be expected to pass proceeds on to good causes or environmental projects.
In Wales it is not just the supermarkets being targeted. Corner shops, butchers, bakers, hotels, cinemas, hairdressers — every retail premise in short — comes under the law. And it is not just plastic bags that must be paid for but also ones made of paper or even plant material. All waste energy, the Welsh government argues.
There are some exemptions. Tony Riley, who has a fruit and veg stall on Machynlleth market, is confused. "I'm selling loose produce so I'm exempt, aren't I?" he says. "I don't think I have to charge, do I?"
He is partly right — food such as fruit, vegetables, fish and meat can be placed into a throwaway bag. But if that bag is put into a carrier bag, that second bag must be paid for. And if someone puts another item into the first bag, say a box of teabags, that would incur a charge.
Many shoppers in Machynlleth – an environmentally aware kind of town – support the law.
"I think it's great," says Roy Brookes, who was carrying the goods he had bought in a rucksack. "We have to try to reduce waste and help the environment." Some stallholders already only provide recycled bags or re-usable ones. "This can only be a good thing," says Liz Barnes, on the Fresh and Local co-operative stall.
But David Thorne on the Thorne and Son butcher's stall says he needed to double bag his products to stop blood dripping everywhere. "Where does that leave me? I won't pass on the charge. It's not fair – they are targeting the poor old customers again at a time when times are hard."
He was glad to hear there will be a three-month "settling in" period to allow retailers to get used to the new legislation during which time enforcement action will be avoided. The government argues that it is not trying to make life harder for hard-up consumers but help them to change their habits.
Down at the Spar store, the manager, Chris Richards, was waiting anxiously for the notices that will explain the charge to customers. "They should have arrived from head office by now but there's no sign of them," he says.
The Spar has been charging customers 2p a bag (which is donated to charity) for the past year. "I don't think people will like paying 5p to start but they'll get used to it," says Richards. "I think it's good we are doing things like this for the environment. Anyway, it'll be an interesting few weeks."
To charge or not to charge – two examples from the Welsh government
1. You could have loose apples, potatoes and pears in one bag and not have to charge. If you then placed a box of tea bags in there too, you would need to apply the charge.
This is to prevent a loophole in the law. A person cannot put an apple in one bag with lots of other shopping, a potato in another bag with lots of other shopping, a lettuce in another etc and get all their single-use carrier bags for free.
This is also to encourage people to think about their behaviour and habits when using single-use carrier bags. The exemptions are there to ensure food safety and protect the consumer from potential cross-contamination from reusable bags.
2. If you went to a fast food restaurant and purchased a packet of fries and a burger then the fries can be placed in a free bag as they are only part-wrapped and you would not be expected to place these in a reusable bag as there could be some food safety risks. If the burger is also placed in the bag, then the bag would be charged for. This is because it is safe to place wrapped food into a reusable bag and the purpose of these regulations is to change customer behaviour every time they shop and in every situation.
